text: Your Wednesday Evening BriefingHere’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
Listen: ‘Modern Love’ PodcastJameela Jamil reads an essay about escaping sexual abuse.
The Book Review PodcastLauren Sandler talks about “This Is All I Got.”

Scientists See Progress in Race to Develop a VaccineIn labs around the world, there is now cautious optimism that a coronavirus vaccine, and perhaps more than one, will be ready sometime next year.The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released more detailed guidance for schools, businesses and transit systems hoping to reopen safely.Ford Motor temporarily stopped production at two newly reopened plants after employees tested positive for the virus. Here’s the latest.
All 50 States Are Now Reopening. But at What Cost?Governors face intensifying pressure to reopen their economies, but experts warn it could mean thousands of new deaths.

Economy
Infections force Ford Motor to suspend production at two reopened plants.
Fed officials worried about the pandemic’s lasting economic damage.
How the ‘Plandemic’ movie and its falsehoods spread widely online.
Global
Brazil authorizes using hydroxychloroquine for Covid-19 patients amid a debate over its efficacy and dangers.
China’s leader sees the pandemic as a crucible to strengthen his rule.
A Nigerian doctors group called for a strike to protest harassment by police officers enforcing a curfew.
New York
Reopening begins in Connecticut.
Over 100 people were found at a Brooklyn synagogue, officials said.
Westchester County will open two beaches to residents only.

Trump Steps Up Attacks on Mail Vote, Making False Claims About MichiganPresident Trump threatened to withhold federal funding for Michigan and Nevada if the states moved forward in expanding vote by mail.

In Crisis, Xi Jinping Sees a Crucible to Strengthen His RuleChina’s leader is using the country’s success — and the criticism against it — to urge the party and the people to weather tough days ahead.
Coronavirus Shut Down the ‘Experience Economy.’ Can It Come Back?Large-scale gatherings are on hold for the foreseeable future. That is taking a toll on the live events industry and society at large.
Returning Office Workers May Face Unexpected Health ThreatsStagnant plumbing systems in emptied commercial buildings could put employees at risk of Legionnaire’s and other illnesses.
A prototype coronavirus vaccine has protected monkeys from infection, researchers said.
Elizabeth Martucci and her son, M.J., recovered from Covid-19, but she said that some neighbors treated them “like a contagion.”  Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
Tittababawassee River flooding parking lots in downtown Midland, Mich. Emily Rose Bennett for The New York Times

Michigan Dam Disaster Threatens Major Dow Toxic-Chemical Superfund SiteFloodwaters surged toward one of the nation’s most extensive toxic cleanup sites, raising concerns of a wider environmental fallout.
More than 300 dams in Michigan have a similar potential for hazard if they fail. See where they are.

For Some Students, Remote Learning Is a Blessing“At home, it seems to be a bit easier to focus on all the work,” said one eighth grader who was struggling in school. “Everything in general is easier.”
Child vaccinations have plummeted 63 percent in New York City, a new hurdle for schools to reopen.
He Was Thriving in New York’s Art Scene. The Virus Changed Everything.Najee Wilson, an artist and muse living in Brooklyn, ponders the future of his New York dream.
The court put the case on a fast track, but it may mean that the full report won’t be seen until after the election.
Nothing to see here! Ana de Armas and Ben Affleck just taking a stroll. Bauer-Griffin/GC Images
Elena Conis, Michael McCoyd and Jessie A. MoravekWhat to Expect When a Coronavirus Vaccine Finally ArrivesThere are sobering lessons from the history of the polio vaccine.
Charlie WarzelI Was Supposed to Eat at a Restaurant. I Bailed.Even in a state that has weathered the pandemic well, going out again raises seemingly endless questions.
Paul ToughGo Ahead, California, Get Rid of the SAT
Nicholas KristofLet’s Remember That the Coronavirus Is Still a Mystery
Gail CollinsWe’ve Got Way Too Many Trumps

Thomas B. EdsallWhen the Mask You’re Wearing ‘Tastes Like Socialism’
Members of Congress Working From Home
Slosh! Slurp! Welcome to the ‘Walktail’ PartyWith most bars still takeout only, indoor gatherings discouraged and the weather warmer, Americans are sipping and strolling.
A Sudden Coronavirus Surge Brought Out Singapore’s Dark SideThe government was blindsided by an outbreak among poor migrant workers in packed dormitories.
New John Maynard Keynes Biography Shows His Relevance TodayIn “The Price of Peace,” Zachary Carter situates the development of Keynes’s economic thought in relation to his social milieu.
